work.p: The topic of these lines bears some similarity to a passage about touch in the opening poem of the first edition of Leaves of Grass," eventually titled "Song of Myself." See, for instance, the lines: "They bribed to swap off with touch, and go and graze at the edges of me, / No consideration, no regard for my draining strength or my anger" (1855, p. 33).

titleStmt.title: Can ? make me
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was preparing materials for the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The lines bear some similarity to lines in the first poem in that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself."

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Can ? make me so exuberant yet so faintish
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Poetic lines on the back of this leaf relate to the poem eventually titled "Faces."

revisionDesc.change: corrected wording of date note based on Ken's advice

add.l: Can ? make me so exuberant yet so faintish?

del.l:
The rage of an unconquerable fierceness is conquered by the touch
tenderest hand

lg.l:
I do not think I am cannot be awake, for nothing looks
or feels to me as it did before,

Or else I am awake for the first time,
and all before has been a mean sleep.
